[justify][author]\033MTerracorp[/author]Dear %s,

landed rulers of the Commonwealth are obligated to report Terraformer activities to us. The machines expand from a [red]Maelstrom[/red] in the sector %s. We want your assessment whether this is an existential threat to all biological life in this outer border galaxy.

[yellow]Xenon Crisis Mechanic:[/yellow]
When the galaxy is in danger Terracorp will force everyone to stop their wars and unite in a big coalition. But since Terracorp has to tend to thousands of other galaxies they cannot pay much attention and rely on Xenon reports from all factions.
The undertone of your own Xenon reports can be changed in the [white]personal journal[/white].
Terracorp listens extra carefully to the absolute majority of combined military power in the Commonwealth. Weak factions with Xenon problems often work towards a global coalition. Strong factions want to prevent it. There is a new diplomatic [white]favor action[/white] which allows to write the Xenon reports for other empires.[/justify]

[justify][author]\033MTerracorp[/author]We just received your report about the global Terraformer progress. According to you they are almost at the gates to Terra itself!
Look, its out of the question that your assessment is valuable to us. But we wonder why your report contradicts our own observations so severely. Please remember that we have to consider the greater picture. Therefore we will only unite the galaxy if biological LIFE itself is at stake. According to our other intel sources this doesn't seem to be the case yet.

Maybe you have your own severe problems with the OCV. Be assured that we send our honest condolences. But we simply cannot take away everyone's freedom to wage their wars as they please. At least not yet.

[yellow]From your Player Journal you are working towards the creation of a global Alliance against the Terraformers. But their global progress is simply too low right now. Terracorp refuses to act right now. No reports can sway them at this point, even if you would use the Xenon Report favor on all factions. Try again when the Xenon own many more sectors or when their fleets have grown much stronger.[/yellow][/justify]

[author][yellow]Tutorial[/yellow][/author]Terracorp has just declared a global [yellow]Xenon Crisis[/yellow]!

> the main faction wars have stopped! Everyone is allied.
> your permanent wars get suppressed until this crisis is over.
> all sectors are Protectorates with severe consequences if you ignore that
> special bounty rewards for OCV and Xenon kills!
> many volunteers have joined the fight! Terracorp covers three quarters of all mercenary costs!

The United Commonwealth needs to fight the Xenon back to their Maelstrom sector. If you win this war the machines will be crippled for a long time. As you read this, all factions have already started to work hard to achieve this goal. What will you do? This is the time when legends and heroes are born!

[author][yellow]Tutorial[/yellow][/author]Traders who do not belong to a main faction can be scanned and killed without damaging your reputation!
However, this will make you a criminal and add to your [yellow]Infamy[/yellow]. Right now you have %s. Both playstyles, criminal or honorable are both viable with different benefits. Infamy slowly decays over time.

[white]Honorable = NO infamy:[/white]
[green]+ the neutral Trader Union frequently bribes you with money[/green]
[green]+ during a Xenon Crisis the UNC forces might gift sectors to you[/green]
[green]+ refugees can come to boost your Taxes and Waste.[/green]

[white]Criminal = 1 or more Infamy:[/white]
[red]----- you cannot get any Truce. \(gaining reputation still possible\).[/red]
[red]--- you cannot buy Sectors or Favor actions.[/red]
[red]-- higher risk that your Zone of Control over adjacent Unknown sectors gets ignored.[/red]
[red]- the Trade Union might fund private security ships instead of you.[/red]
[red]- no Police License for you[/red]
[green]+++ Free Loot from robbing the weak![/green]
[green]+++ Pirates tend to leave you and your buisness partners alone[/green]
[green]++ Nomad mercs fear you, stay for longer and will never turn rogue on you[/green]
[green]+ better Spaceweed production and client ships can come to buy directly[/green]
[green]+ increased Mercenary recruitment range.[/green]
> most criminal effects get more intense with more infamy, but having any infamy at all usually already has the largest impact.

[white]Gaining Infamy:[/white]
- destroying neutral Traders, Nomad ships and especially refugee transports.
- boarding ships with marines
- breaking truces and non aggression agreements
- violating the galactic peace during a Xenon Crisis

[white]Loosing Infamy:[/white]
- waiting. About 6 points will decay each ingame day.
- a general amnesty will clear most of it at once after a Xenon Crisis.
> if you accumulate too much infamy \(about 10-15 points\) it will become almost impossible to get rid of it from natural decay.

[author][green]Freelancer Trade Union[/green][/author]You have been registered in our special philantropist program and received %s credits from the Freelancer Relief Fund.

We thank you for your peaceful interaction with the civilian sector and hope for a lasting partnership.

[yellow]Tutorial:[/yellow]
The neutral Traders in this galaxy are organized. They basically just bribed you. Its a reward which gets frequently paid as long as you don't have any infamy.
The amount of credits depends on your combined military power in relation to the other main factions. It won't cover your entire ship maintenance, but it is a reliable secondary income.

[author][green]GalNewsNet[/green][/author]The United Commonwealth has declared victory over the dreadful Xenon Empire.
Our brave soldiers will send them back through their hellish Maelstrom in the sector %s. Where they will hopefully stay forever!
Our species have proven that we can stand united side by side.

[yellow]Tutorial:[/yellow]
The OCV and Xenon are completely crippled and won't be able to reinforce their fleets for a while. But eventually they will return.
The main empires might be pretty burned out of resources by now. That's why they want to keep the peace for some time and try to rebuild this galaxy.

[author]Flagship of the Nomad Fleet[/author]To everyone fleeing from the Xenon Empire,

We are experienced survivors of countless other galaxies that the OCV destroyed before yours.

Never give up buddy! We have work for your wife and kids in our factory ships. Listen, you don't really have any options left, so this is the deal. We give you a military ship, you go earn some cash and then pay us back...

[yellow]Tutorial:[/yellow]
The [yellow]Nomads[/yellow] are a new wandering alien faction. They follow the OCV into other galaxies to exploit the refugee chaos that the machines leave behind. The Nomad elite lives in their Flagship, a mobile shipyard. Desperate refugees who arrive at the Nomad Flagship get armed and sent back into the galaxy to become mercs for hire. But they have lots of debt and their families are being held hostage.

Nomad mercs work for [yellow]half the price[/yellow]. But they are not very experienced or disciplined. Eventually they run away \(stealing the upfront hiring fee\), or even try their luck as a new pirate gang! Only an [yellow]infamous[/yellow] leader could keep them in line long enough to build a real merc army.

[yellow]Tutorial[/yellow][/author]You have just received %s new people in your %s! They are [yellow]Refugees[/yellow] from a sector which got attacked by the Terraformers.

Refugees will only come to your Outposts if you are honorable \(no infamy\). This allows to exceed the usual population limit by up to the double amount to get more Taxes, Waste generation and production speed. But keep in mind that these additional people cannot regrow naturally if you start building ships, which requires pilots, or if a desease or famine reduces your total population.

Harming innocent refugees would quickly turn you into a very evil person. And you wouldn't want that, do you?

[author]Nomad John Doe[/author]Fellow Nomads! The time has come for us to take revenge on the Xenon who destroyed our home stations! Wipe the machines from the face of this galaxy!

Avenge your families!

Honor your fallen brothers and sisters!

Follow me! WE ATTACK!

[yellow]Tutorial:[/yellow]
The Nomad Mercs in the galaxy have gone crazy. The fools are currently betraying all contracts and just rush into the Xenon Empire in an unorganized manner. Their blind rage will cause them to attack everyone, but they will probably not return anyway.

[author][yellow]Tutorial[/yellow][/author][white]What is QuickTrade?

The default mindset of your Outpost is to keep every ware stored inside unless you specifically allow to sell something.
The problem with this is that random Loot piles up everywhere. Same for the color minerals that your Miners frequently haul inside. And even worse, your Traders will use the Outpost storage for their inventory management. They often dump something inside the Outpost just to free up their cargohold. On default this junk just never gets sold and your Traders will slowly burn money away.


The solution is QuickTrade. Its just a set of buttons which act as shortcuts to quickly set up trade settings on an Outpost so that the station fills a specific role in your empire.

For example you might want to keep almost everything in Outpost A to build your ships there. But Outpost B should make money and only keep the food that it needs, together with resources that it supplies to nearby factories.

Now you would combine the various Quicktrade modules on both Outposts. Be aware that they can partially override each other. Its always best to think which wares you want to keep, rather than what you want to sell. Because you will certainly forget something and then never think of that hidden stockpile of red minerals which could be sold for 2 million credits.

Apply QuickTrade modules from top to bottom. I recommend to start with the first one - SELL ALL - literally all the time, on pretty much every Outpost. And then tell them what resources they need to keep. Doing it this way will make you very rich quickly, especially if you also open trade for other factions.


All of the RESERVE modules tell the Outpost to keep something stored and only start selling if the Outpost accumulates an unnecessarily large stockpile.

All SUPPLY modules work similar to the Reserve modules, but Supply also sets up small buy orders to generate an influx of resources from outside your empire.[/white]

[author][yellow]Tutorial[/yellow][/author]Welcome to the [yellow]Chaotic galaxy start[/yellow]! \(you selected it in the galaxy generator\)

This plays a bit different.
The OCV begins with powerful invader fleets and over the next couple hours the Xenon receive extra defense fleets for their already large territory. They tend to put them close to the OCV Maelstrom in %s.


All empires will soon band together.

During this massive war Terracorp says that its illegal to fight each other.

Right from the beginning all empty unknown sectors can be claimed by anyone. You might need to get creative to start your empire. Waiting in SETA mode is also viable. New empty areas often appear during the crisis.

[justify][author]\033R%s Expansion Minister[/author]Dear leader of the Independents,

the great %s empire hereby declares war on you! We will do the galaxy a favor by ridding it of your insolence and this little upstart kingdom that you created!


[yellow]Terracorp law demands that if your two nations ever sign a formal peace again, then this will be a longer lasting Non-Aggression-Pact instead of the basic Truce.[/yellow][/justify]

[author][green]GalNewsNet[/green][/author]...
........
.....
...thanks Cassandra. Back to the studio.
...
Now lets talk about this new organization.
Lead by their charismatic leader who we just know as the [white]Independent[/white], they have [yellow]%s[/yellow]. Strategic experts claim that multiple governments are planning preemtive strikes against them.
Harry, your assessment please. What are we facing?
Well, Jonah. You see, this group works like a cult. The Independent holds all the power, but he got no legitimacy. Look, this is gonna happen...

[yellow]Tutorial:[/yellow]
The galactic public noticed your overall progress and starts to treat you more like an ambitious nation and less like a harmless private corporation.

The following effects only apply on the hardest game difficulty or when you have activated the war system also for easy and normal difficulty in the t-file.

From now on other factions are allowed to declare war on you!
Good reputation means nothing and gets trumped by strategic interests.
- every military ship under your control helps to prevent war declarations against you \(deterrence\).
- all factions primarily want to control their dejure sectors. Terrans want terran memory sectors. If you own any of these you give that faction much more reason to go to war with you.
- most of the time it will be your neighbors who declare war
- lots of factors dictate their overall desire to declare war. Coalitions, Total Wars, Xenon troubles, faction strength. Use common sense! If a strong neighbor doesn't have any major enemies he will eventually betray you.
- you started as %s. They tend to be much more loyal.
- certain races are naturally more aggressive than others \(good vs. evil Ethos\).

[justify][author]\033R%s Expansion Minister[/author]Leader of the Independents,\n\nwe are horrified by your terrorist attack on a %s. Who is next? We all agreed to fight our wars in a civilized fashion, but apparently you are just a criminal maniac. We will not tolerate your actions![/justify]

[justify][author]\033R%s Expansion Minister[/author]Dear leader of the Independents,\n\nplease note that the galactic community has agreed that boarding with marines is terrorism. We noticed you stealing a %s and are very disappointed.[/justify]

[author][yellow]Boarding Tutorial for Zero Hour[/yellow][/author]- Marines and boarding pods get sold by pirate bases.
- boarding is considered terrorism and might have diplomatic consequences.
- boarding unlocks first quarter of the ship blueprint
- the enemy always makes one final last stand after you have already won the ship. Think of a kamikaze ambush or a boobytrapped ship bridge. You will suffer additional marine losses depending on how many of your soldiers have reached the final boarding stage.

[justify][author]\033YTutorial[/author]\033WIt seems like you are pretty broke. You will need more money to buy important resources.

Tips:

> be careful with automatic Traders if Pirates are still a problem in your sectors. Group your freighters up by sending one of them to a trading station and have all the others follow him. Trade a lot of different wares at once and guard your convoy with all available military ships.
Try to connect your Outpost and the trading station with jump beacons.

> add a ware that you can sell to the Outpost's trade list with import and export thresholds at 0. The best examples are foods like Vegetables or Fish that your Outposts will constantly produce if they have the food that the population demands. Its always better to fulfill these demands because then the population generates twice as much of another food. Sell that and you already get some good passive income. For the time being you should also allow foreign Traders to visit your Outposts. Don't worry! They will respect your trade rules and cannot steal important resources that you did not allow to sell.

> build an Advanced Satellite factory and give it some money. Then allow Traders to come and trade. This will always be profitable even if you have to buy all the energy cells for this station.

> the bounty board in your player console might be very useful right now.

> visit a faction sector which has a lot of factories and start doing some Cargo Taxi jobs by registering your freighter in the Personal Console. This earns some quick bucks to stay afloat with lots of additional reputation to balance out your future territorial expansion.

> certain Perks generate some ware for free or save resources that you won't need to buy as much. Like Cheaper Stations, No food consumption, Solar Panels, Spaceweed Production, or Tax.

> go scan some NPC miners with your Data Scanner, buy 16 mobile drilling systems at a trading station and start building 4 miners for your sector. They generate decent profit over time, but only if you actually sell their output. So add color crystals and minerals on the trade list! The best way to do this is via QuickTrade in Logistics>Traders.[/justify]

[justify][author]\033YTutorial[/author]\033WYou already own quite a lot of sectors, but your military power is still weak. Of course it can be useful to reserve nearby empty sectors for later use, but be careful! You are playing on a difficulty level where the AI watches your overall progress and can eventually declare war. You should have a plan how to get money, resources and military power besides only having a large territory. Only military power will deter other factions from declaring war you. If you keep expanding into more sectors at all costs you will might attract lots of powerful invasions and loose the game.[/justify]

[justify][author]\033YTutorial[/author]You need to choose a starting sector for your empire.

All your sectors project a [yellow]Zone of Control[/yellow] \(ZoC\) over adjacent empty Unknown sectors.

Other factions are much less likely to claim sectors inside your ZoC. So plan your early strategy around this concept. Select sectors so that you protect many additional empty sectors and reserve them for your future expansion.

There are no guarantees that nobody is gonna claim these sectors, but you greatly increase the odds that they remain available for a long time.

Factions can still violate your ZoC, especially if you have infamy. On hard game difficulty ZoC is generally less reliable and the other factions can even send Explorers past your sectors to claim empty sectors behind them.[/justify]

[justify][author]\033YTutorial[/author][white]Seems like you got your hands on a capship. It might be wise to recycle this [/white]%s[white] to quickly unlock its blueprint with a massive research bonus. This can be done in any Outpost. Unlocking the rest of the blueprint in your research station will be very quick. You even get half of the resources back, so its only a small loss. With General commands > Strip you can remove all weapons and shields beforehand and reuse them once you have built another [/white]%s.[/justify]

[justify][author]\033YTutorial[/author]\033WYou have aquired some marines.

Now you only need Boarding pods. They get sold on pirate stations or can be crafted with the Outpost Missle Manufacture perk.
You can recruit marine volunteers for free on any Outpost, but they start with very low skills.
You always need some veteran marines too. Those are only sold at pirate stations.

To board a ship you can shoot boarding pods like missles or use the boarding command in the Hacking section of the ship command console.

Your Marines need a certain combined fighting skill to pass and survive all battles through various ship decks. Some mechanical skill is required to break the ship hull, and Hacking skill to unlock the ship core. Engineering skill only lowers collateral damage to the ship hull.

Your losses depend on combined fighting skill and on how many marines you send. More marines means more of them will get killed. Don't send elite teams of highly skilled marines against low value targets like an M6.

All you need is one decent hacker who reaches the final ship deck and one good mechanic for each boarding pod fired. Each pod can hold 5 marines.
All ships can carry 15 marines. TPs can store 60 marines.
A Transporter Device allows for remote marine exchange between ships.
Only TM, M6, M7, M8, M1 and M2 can be boarded.
You can fire additional boarding pods during the operation. For example to send marines with hacking skill later during the fight and increase their chances of survival.[/justify]

[justify][author]\033YTutorial[/author]\033WYou just suffered random marine losses on the final bridge of the ship. For each boarding operation there is a kamikaze ambush or boobytrap explosion at the very end, which can kill additional marines. The difference to the deck fights before is that fighting skill does not help to prevent marine losses. It only matters how many marines have reached the ship bridge. The more crowded it is, the more losses you will suffer. These losses are completely random and can easily kill high skill marines.\n\nThis means that there is an incentive for you to only send just enough skilled marines so that you can pass all skill checks and win the ship, but without loosing many high level marines in the final casualty round. To reduce your losses you can try to board with few high skill marines or with a mixed team that also has some rookie volunteers. Those can be hired en masse on your Outposts. They add a little bit of fighting skill to your side, but its no real loss if they die. What matters most are your veteran fighters and mechanical or hacking specialists.[/justify]

[justify][author]\033YTutorial[/author]\033WThe best bounties are usually put on Pirate Gangs. If you kill the leader their morale breaks and they scatter in different directions.
Hunting gang leaders is a good way to make lots of money during the earlier stages of your playthrough. Especially since you don't need to defeat the entire pirate gang and only kill their leader.

Other frequent bounties are Pirate Raid Carrier TM. They transport pirate fighters over larger distances and drop them near their victims. The bounty increases with each hot drop. But the TM is very fast, decently shielded and always wants to escape you so it might be hard to catch.
If a TM grows a too large bounty it can return to a pirate base for a hull respray. Its like removing wanted level in GTA.[/justify]

[justify][author]\033YTutorial[/author]\033WYour Jump Beacons will attract small Xenon scouts which can turn them against you and create teleport routes for Xenon fleets.

Its highly recommended that you guard each beacon with at least 1 M3 fighter. Its enough to park a ship nearby in space without giving any orders. It automatically attacks approaching Xenon scouts and you will get notified at the bottom of your screen. This also works if you tell that ship to Escort:Protect the beacon itself.

Owning more jump beacons will increase the frequency at which Xenon scouts try to infect one of them. But its usually well worth it to claim jump beacons if they help your travel network in any way. You just need to protect them.[/justify]

[justify][author]\033YTutorial[/author]\033WYou already played for a while, but i don't see any larger ships like frigates in your fleet.
Did you know that pirate bases often contain an M7? The pirate boss will try to escape and if you scare him fast enough by draining his shields he will bail out and you can claim the ship. If you take too long with the shields he will become too confident and not bail out.

Anoher fast way to unlock larger ships is to steal one with marines or the Oxygen virus hack and then reverse engineering it in an Outpost recycling bay for a massive research boost.[/justify]

[justify][author]\033YTutorial[/author][white]Your sector[/white] %s [white]has a lot of pirates flying around in it. They are probably coming from some Pirate Base in the general area.
The Pirates are less aggressive than the Xenon and often wait for easy targets like TS and TP. Those freighters can usually flee to a station before their shields get breached, but heavy pirate activity prevents them from doing their work and makes long trips very risky.

Tips:

> to thin out the pirate horde you can set up a fast picket fleet of about 3 fighters. Anyone should be able to afford such a small security investment. Use the following fleet settings and they should survive well:
Monitor all sectors of this faction: PLAYER
Retreat from enemy ship class: M6
Scanning range: 0 KM
Followers engage commanders target: YES
Ignore: BIG SHIPS and FREIGHTERS

> consider not using your current freighters as Agents, Miners or Traders yet. Instead form them up into a large convoy for better safety and buy or sell manually with this entire group for now. Keep them together and also combine all your military ships to protect them.

> use TM or M6 as Looters instead of TS or TP Pirates mostly like to attack freighters

> gain infamy. All pirates will attack you much less if you are a criminal like them.

> open your stations to NPC Traders so you don't need to send freighters of your own. Stations with a resource input should be given some money to buy it. Keeping stations idle for long is always a waste because they would all produce something more valuable if you just manage to keep them running. This includes your Outposts which need food but can produce twice as much other food plus additional resources for free.

> unlock the Pirate Contract perk if you are completely surrounded or desperate

> with a fleet of about 3 M6 and a dozen M3 fighters you can start destroying pirate bases near your empire. This will help greatly in the long run.[/white][/justify]

[justify][author]\033YTutorial[/author]%s is a dejure sector for the %s. It has sentimental value to them, like an ancestral home planet or a holy place. Factions generally desire to control their dejure sectors and don't like it when they are controlled by someone else. Battlegroups will often focus to conquer these sectors first.\n\nYou are playing on a difficulty level which allows the AI to declare war on you. Just you controlling %s already gives the %s a major incentive to go to war with you. If you want to reduce the risk of getting surprised by undesired conflicts in the future it might be best to hand it over to them. This can be done from the personal console.[/justify]

[justify][author]\033YTutorial[/author]%s is a Terran Memory Sector.

By building a research station here you can unlock terran ship designs. Other factions can also build terran ships in these sectors.

The Terrans don't like their shiny tech getting bastardized like that and generally want all memory sectors for themselves. So their Battlegroups will often focus on these sectors first.

You are playing on a difficulty level which allows the AI to declare war on you. Just you controlling %s already gives the Terrans a major incentive to go to war with you. If you want to avoid conflict with them in the future it might be best to hand it over to them. This can be done from the personal console.[/justify]

[justify][author]\033YTutorial[/author]You have just built your first factory, a %s.

From time to time it needs to get visited by a freighter so it can keep running. Resources must be delivered and finished products hauled away. Mayhem 3 doesn't have self sufficient complexes, so cargo transport is always a thing but with many different solutions!

In general there are three different ways how you can organize all the shipping logistics in your empire. There is no universal best method as all of them have their uses.

1\) Manual Shipping
Don't underestimate how long a single visit by a freighter can keep a factory supplied and running.
During the earlygame many players struggle with pirates attacking their freighters. The easiest fix is to send a freighter with a manual command and deliver resources only when its quite safe. For example after a dangerous pirate group has just left your sector. Don't be ashamed if you have to group up all your ships and fly from station to station if need be.

2\) Automatic Closed Economy
Eventually you want a network of Agent Workers to distribute most resources between your stations. Their homebase can be a factory but an Outpost is recommended.
In Logistics>Agents you can tell each Outpost which wares its Agents should gather or redustribute from there.
Its best to apply the 'Complete' job template which covers all relevant factories and make further changes if needed. The Outpost Worker range determines how far your Agents are allowed to go on the galaxy map.

3\) Free Trade
Each station will either allow foreign traders to come and trade, or it forbids them from doing so. On player stations its blocked by default but you can always turn it on.
Especially during the earlygame it can be very useful to allow trade on certain stations. Sometimes your freighters are unable to reach your stations because of pirates. Then you can just pay other factions do the hauling for you. The refinement process in your factories earns enough profit for this. A major advantage is that you can keep all your freighters docked safely but your factories can already start producing. This allows for quicker overall economic growth. Later you can switch to a closed economy and forbid trade again.

Most factories will need about 100k credits starting capital to buy their first resources. Its almost impossible to loose money here as long as you keep selling what you produce and don't stockpile it too much.

Your Outpost will only trade wares that you have added to a special trade list in Logistics>Traders

The downside of allowing trade is that you often want to produce something primarily for your own consumption, but you cannot prevent that a Trader sometimes takes resources to another faction. That's why you should forbid trade for a few strategically important ship part factories like Hull Plating or Crystal fabs.[/justify]

[justify][author]\033YTutorial[/author]Claiming %s consumed most of your %s reputation. Its no immediate problem, but to be able to expand more towards their borders and remain friendly you should earn more goodwill.

A fast and efficient but slightly grindy remedy are missions and cargo hauler or taxi jobs.

A passive way to earn reputation is defending %s sectors with some automated fleets like these:


Hunt Pirate Fighters:
3 M3 with fleet settings > Monitor faction: %s, Retreat from class: M6, Scanning range: 0 KM, Followers attack commanders target: YES, Ignore: Big ships and freighters

Hunt Pirate Corvettes:
1 M7 + 3 M6 with fleet settings > Monitor faction: %s, Retreat from class: Large capships, Scanning range: 10 KM, Followers attack commanders target: NO, Target priority for huge ships: big ships, Ignore: Fighters and freighters [/justify]

[justify][author]\033YTutorial[/author]You don't have many %s left.

This is one of the 4 important components that are required to produce ships with their shields and lasers.

You should always try to refill Computers, Hull Plating, Quantum Tubes and the basic non colored Crystals as soon as you start to run out. It is often required to buy more of these before you have built all the required factories.

%s might be difficult to find on the open market. Terracorp forbids trading stations to deal with high-end ship parts.

But you can always buy them directly from %s factories and sometimes also certain faction Outposts with very large stockpiles.

If you give a freighter the command Trade-Run:Buy %s he might find such a high quantity seller.
Trade Run is an automated trade command. Your guy gives the station a call so that they already reserve the wares for him. Trader Workers also do this.

Its quite common that automatic trade cannot find a seller. This just means that everyone is only offering small amounts which cannot be bought with automated trade.
But all factories always have at least a little bit of product ready. They are willing to sell it to you if you tell a freighter to dock and then do the trade manually. To find these stations you should use the Trade Product Search command. Paying a higher price is still a good deal if it helps to get this ware at all.

When everything fails you can craft %s with the mobile factory in your TL. But this consumes way more resources than normal factories.[/justify]

[justify][author]\033YTutorial[/author]The %s want to create a coalition against the %s. You can see this in the relations tab of your Ministry of War \(Personal Console\).

A coalition is an alliance of multiple smaller factions with the shared goal of massively reducing the territory size of a larger empire. This forges a close bond between the partners.

You can become part of this too. Either as a small member or a large target. From the diplomacy screen you can declare that you desire a coalition against another empire.
A coalition gets created when two factions want a coalition against the same enemy. Factions may also join into existing coalitions.

If you were to declare your desire for a coalition against the %s right now, then this would create a coalition with the %s.

A coalition has certain benefits:

> your partners will never declare war on you \(this is only relevant for the hardest game difficulty\)
> you can activate free diplomatic favor actions
> your partners won't mind if you conquer sectors at their borders

You can always revoke your coalition desire unless you are already a coalition member. At this point you cannot leave anymore and have to fight like you promised before. Coalitions only get dissolved when the targeted enemy faction eventually owns less sectors than the largest coalition member.[/justify]
